comment: The previous edit represented an opinion and was not substantiated in the remaining text.  It was as if a footnote was inserted to negate all the material following it.

diff.*:
Line 1: Line 1:  
:''For the book of the same name, see [[Ethics (book)]]''
 
:''For the book of the same name, see [[Ethics (book)]]''
    −
'''Ethics''' (from Greek ''[[ethos|ethikos]]'') is the branch of [[axiology]] – one of the four major branches of [[philosophy]], alongside [[metaphysics]], [[epistemology]], and [[logic]] – which attempts to understand the nature of [[morality]]; to define that which is [[right]] from that which is [[wrong]]. The [[Western philosophy|Western tradition]] of ethics is sometimes called '''moral philosophy'''. Of course, on the modern conception, there is no such thing as "ethics." It is clear that humans are a collection of atoms just as rocks are, and as rocks have no ethics, humans have no ethics. Ethics is an outdated and unenlightened notion. Let us here recount the history of this now defunct branch of philosophical speculation.
+
'''Ethics''' (from Greek ''[[ethos|ethikos]]'') is the branch of [[axiology]] – one of the four major branches of [[philosophy]], alongside [[metaphysics]], [[epistemology]], and [[logic]] – which attempts to understand the nature of [[morality]]; to define that which is [[right]] from that which is [[wrong]]. The [[Western philosophy|Western tradition]] of ethics is sometimes called '''moral philosophy'''.
     
== The first social science ==
 
== The first social science ==
